awd_titl_txt: International Global Atmospheric Chemistry International Project Office (IGAC-IPO) 2021-2024
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports the International Project Office (IPO) of the International Global Atmospheric Chemistry (IGAC) Project, a project of the international Commission on Atmospheric Composition and Global Pollution and a Global Research Project under the umbrella of Future Earth.  The three focal areas of IGAC activity are (1) Fostering Community, (2) Building Capacity, and (3) Providing Leadership.  The IGAC IPO facilitates international scientific collaborations, cultivates the next generation of scientists, builds capacity in developing countries, and fosters a cohesive international community of atmospheric scientists working together across disciplines and geographical boundaries to address global change and sustainability issues. This project is jointly supported by NSF, NASA, and NOAA.

IGAC’s priorities and activities are determined and guided by an international volunteer Scientific Steering Committee (SSC).  The main responsibility of the IGAC International Project Office’s (IPO) is to implement these priorities in collaboration with SSC members and other members of the international atmospheric chemistry community.  The responsibilities of the IPO include: administering projects on a day-to-day basis under the guidance of the SSC; supporting the SSC in planning and carrying out IGAC’s mission and goals; working with the SSC and the community on coordinating IGAC activities and national and regional working groups; serving as a channel of communication between scientists working in different countries on various aspects of global change and sustainability; organizing events, workshops, and capacity building activities; promoting IGAC activities and events via newsletters, email lists, website, social media, presentations, etc.; interacting with relevant policy and stakeholder communities; serving as liaison with scientific sponsors, funding agencies and host institutions; and creating and maintaining an archive of key core project documents.  For developing country scientists, IGAC fosters the creation of a strong cohesive community of atmospheric scientists in under-represented regions of the world and also connects the scientists to the larger IGAC community in order to foster international collaborations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The International Global Atmospheric Chemistry (IGAC) Project provides a framework for international networking in atmospheric chemistry. As the atmosphere is global, many questions on atmospheric chemistry require collaboration across borders to effectively answer. IGAC is a free to join international community, with ~1500 people on the mailing list, 300-700 conference attendees, and a number of champions leading working groups and activities. Day to day operations are led by a director, who is guided by an international Scientific Steering Committee (SSC) comprised of mid and senior career scientists.

 

To facilitate networking, IGAC hosts biennial science conferences. Two took place during this reporting period, one in Manchester, UK in 2022 and one in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia in 2024. Each conference had representatives from over 40 countries and over 400 attendees. One plenary session took place in each conference, with different sessions on air quality and impacts, atmospheric chemistry and weather, atmospheric chemistry at interfaces (e.g., dust, ice, snow), fundamental lab studies of atmospheric chemistry, emerging models and measurement technology, and other sessions. Poster sessions and networking sessions, as well as early career researcher specific skill sessions, are also a part of these conferences. Before each conference, IGAC hosted an early career short course, planned by an international committee of early career researchers guided by the SSC and attended by 40 competitively chosen early career scientists. Short course attendees received travel grants on a need basis and sessions included networking events, field trips relevant to atmospheric chemistry, and training sessions on models, data use, and field mission planning.

 

IGAC also sponsors a number of activities, centered around atmospheric chemistry science questions that need global collaboration to address. During this reporting period, eight activities continued and three new activities began (one on small sensor use, Allin Wayra, one on biomass burning emissions and uncertainties, BBURNED, and one on urban air pollution and interactions with climate, U-APIC). These activities are proposed and lead by the community with guidance from the IGAC director and SSC.  Each of these activities hosted workshops, training schools, wrote review papers, and had other deliverables associated with their specific topic.

 

In addition to activities, IGAC sponsors several regional working groups, to connect researchers in a region where there may be strong scientists but no regional community, and to connect that community to the global community. Some of these working groups have written review papers, given journalist trainings, have regional conferences, and support regional early career scientists.

 

Finally, IGAC works to advance atmospheric chemists of the future through early career programs, including a newly established early career researcher steering committee. This steering committee planned a virtual networking conference in 2023, a monthly virtual skills webinar, a website, and a mailing list specifically for early career researchers and opportunities.
